message_text:
<paper>
Paper Title: Evolutionary dynamics of higher-order interactions in social networks
Paper Abstract: We live and cooperate in networks. However, links in networks only allow for pairwise interactions, thus making the framework suitable for dyadic games, but not for games that are played in larger groups. Here, we study the evolutionary dynamics of a public goods game in social systems with higher-order interactions. First, we show that the game on uniform hypergraphs corresponds to the replicator dynamics in the well-mixed limit, providing a formal theoretical foundation to study cooperation in networked groups. Second, we unveil how the presence of hubs and the coexistence of interactions in groups of different sizes affects the evolution of cooperation. Finally, we apply the proposed framework to extract the actual dependence of the synergy factor on the size of a group from real-world collaboration data in science and technology. Our work provides a way to implement informed actions to boost cooperation in social groups.
</paper>

<paper_classification>
"contribution" = proposes something new (method, technique, dataset, framework, benchmark, etc.)
"survey" = literature review, overview, meta-analysis, position papers (only references existing work)
</paper_classification>

<entity_types>
task      - Problem being solved (image classification, theorem proving, protein folding)
method    - Technique, algorithm, procedure (gradient descent, CRISPR, induction)
data      - Datasets, databases, benchmarks (ImageNet, MNIST, arXiv corpus)
artifact  - Pre-built: trained models, proof libraries (GPT-4, Mathlib, Cas9)
tool      - Software, instruments, platforms (PyTorch, Lean prover, microscope)
concept   - Abstract ideas, theories, frameworks (attention, category theory)
other     - Entities that don't fit above categories
</entity_types>

<relations>
uses     - Anything EXISTING that the paper uses (methods, datasets, tools, concepts, tasks)
proposes - Anything NEW/NOVEL that the paper creates or introduces

VALIDATION REQUIREMENTS:
- ALL papers MUST have at least 1 "uses" (papers always build on existing work)
- CONTRIBUTION papers MUST have at least 1 "proposes" (they must create something new)
</relations>

<output_json>
{
  "paper_type": "contribution" or "survey",
  "triples": [
    {
      "name": "Wikipedia Article Title",
      "relation": "uses|proposes",
      "entity_type": "task|method|data|artifact|tool|concept|other",
      "wikipedia_url": "https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/...",
      "relevance": "Why this matters (1 sentence)"
    }
  ]
}
</output_json>

<YOUR_TODO_LIST>
FIRST, add ALL of these to your todo list with "TodoWrite" tool:

CRITICAL: Todo content must be copied exactly as is written here, with NO CHANGES. These todos are intentionally detailed so that another LLM could read each one without any external context and understand exactly what it has to do.

1. Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple:
   - name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm")
   - relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes)
   - entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other
   - wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/)
   - relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

<CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
When using WebSearch, you MUST use the allowed_domains parameter:
WebSearch(query="[your query]", allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"])

This ensures only English Wikipedia results are returned. Do NOT search without allowed_domains.
</CRITICAL_WEBSEARCH_INSTRUCTIONS>
</YOUR_TODO_LIST>

Begin now.

## Hypergraph

A hypergraph is a generalization of a graph in which an edge can join any number of vertices.(no content)In contrast, in an ordinary graph, an edge connects exactly two vertices.

### Key Properties and Applications

Hypergraphs are useful in modeling satisfiability problems, databases, machine learning, and Steiner tree problems, and have been extensively used in machine learning tasks with applications including recommender systems, image retrieval, and bioinformatics.

### Related Concepts

- **k-uniform hypergraphs**: A hypergraph whose edges all have size k is called k-uniform, where a 2-uniform hypergraph is a graph.

- **Matching**: A matching in a hypergraph is a set of hyperedges, in which every two hyperedges are disjoint.

- **Vertex cover**: A vertex cover in a hypergraph is a set of vertices, such that every hyperedge of the hypergraph contains at least one vertex of that set.

- **Intersection graph**: The line graph of a hypergraph H is the graph whose vertex set is the set of the hyperedges of H, with two vertices adjacent when their corresponding hyperedges have a nonempty intersection in H.

Links: [{"title":"Replicator equation - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_equation"},{"title":"Evolutionary game theory - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_game_theory"},{"title":"Chicken (game) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Chicken_(game)"},{"title":"Replicator - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator"},{"title":"Replicator (cellular automaton) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(cellular_automaton)"},{"title":"Replicator (United States military) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(United_States_military)"},{"title":"Self-replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replication"},{"title":"Replicator (Star Trek) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_(Star_Trek)"},{"title":"Self-replicating machine - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Self-replicating_machine"},{"title":"DNA replication - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Template_replication"}]

Based on the search results, here's what replicator dynamics is:

## Definition and Core Concept

Replicator dynamics is a type of dynamical system used in evolutionary game theory to model how the frequency of strategies in a population changes over time.(no content)It is a simple model of strategy change where a strategy which does better than the average increases in frequency at the expense of strategies that do worse than the average.

## Key Characteristics

It is a deterministic, monotone, non-linear, and non-innovative dynamic that captures the principle of natural selection.(no content)The replicator dynamics models heredity but not mutation, and assumes asexual reproduction for the sake of simplicity.

## How It Works

The growth rate of the proportion of organisms using a certain strategy is equal to the difference between the average payoff of that strategy and the average payoff of the population as a whole.

## Applications

Replicator dynamics have been widely applied in fields such as biology (to study evolution and population dynamics), economics (to analyze bounded rationality and strategy evolution), and machine learning (particularly in multi-agent systems and reinforcement learning).

## Analysis

Since the replicator equation is non-linear, an exact solution is difficult to obtain, so the equation is usually analyzed in terms of stability.

I've completed the web search for "social networks." Here are the key findings:

## What is a Social Network?

A social network is a social structure consisting of a set of social actors (such as individuals or organizations), networks of dyadic ties, and other social interactions between actors.

## Social Networking Services

A social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)Social networking sites facilitate building networks of contacts to exchange various types of content online and allow these computer-mediated interactions to link members of various networks and help create, sustain and develop new social and professional relationships.

## History of Social Networks

Early social networking on the World Wide Web began with generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), which focused on bringing people together to interact through chat rooms and encouraged users to share personal information via personal web pages.(no content)In the late 1990s, user profiles became a central feature of social networking sites, allowing users to compile lists of "friends" and search for other users with similar interests.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

A social networking service is an online platform that people use to build social networks or social relationships with other people who share similar personal or career interests, activities, backgrounds or real-life connections.(no content)Social networking sites facilitate building networks of contacts to exchange various types of content online and allow these computer-mediated interactions to link members of various networks and help create, sustain and develop new social and professional relationships.

## History of Social Networks

Early social networking on the World Wide Web began with generalized online communities such as Theglobe.com (1995), GeoCities (1994) and Tripod.com (1995), which focused on bringing people together to interact through chat rooms and encouraged users to share personal information via personal web pages.(no content)In the late 1990s, user profiles became a central feature of social networking sites, allowing users to compile lists of "friends" and search for other users with similar interests.

## Social Network Analysis

Social network analysis (SNA) is the process of investigating social structures through the use of networks and graph theory, characterizing networked structures in terms of nodes (individual actors, people, or things within the network) and ties, edges, or links (relationships or interactions) that connect them.

Links: [{"title":"Interaction (statistics) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction_(statistics)"},{"title":"Interactome - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interactome"},{"title":"Sparsity-of-effects principle - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Sparsity-of-effects_principle"},{"title":"Fractional factorial design - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Fractional_factorial_design"},{"title":"Network motif - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_motif"},{"title":"Hub (network science) - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Network_hub"},{"title":"Hierarchical network model - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hierarchical_network_model"},{"title":"Protein–protein interaction - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Protein–protein_interaction"},{"title":"Interaction nets - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Interaction_nets"},{"title":"Betweenness centrality - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Betweenness_centrality"}]

Based on the web search results, here's what I found about higher-order interactions networks:

The search results primarily cover higher-order interactions in statistical contexts and various network types. Here are the key findings:

## Statistical Definition

When there are more than two explanatory variables, several interaction variables are constructed, with pairwise-products representing pairwise-interactions and higher order products representing higher order interactions.

## Application in Experiments

In the statistical analysis of the results from factorial experiments, the sparsity-of-effects principle states that a system is usually dominated by main effects and low-order interactions, making it most likely that main effects and two-factor interactions are the most significant responses in a factorial experiment, while higher order interactions such as three-factor interactions are very rare.

## Network Contexts

The search results also reference higher-order structures in biological networks. For instance, the Sirt-1 protein interactome and Sirt family second order interactome is the network involving Sirt-1 and its directly interacting proteins where as second order interactome illustrates interactions up to second order of neighbors.

Additionally, network motifs are sub-graphs that repeat themselves in a specific network or even among various networks, and each of these sub-graphs, defined by a particular pattern of interactions between vertices, may reflect a framework in which particular functions are achieved efficiently.

The results suggest that higher-order interactions represent complex relationships between multiple variables or entities in networks, though they are generally less common than lower-order interactions in many real-world systems.

Here are the search results for "cooperation game theory":

## Overview of Cooperative Game Theory

Cooperative game theory is a branch of game theory that deals with the study of games where players can form coalitions, cooperate with one another, and make binding agreements.(no content)In game theory, a cooperative or coalitional game is a game with groups of players who form binding "coalitions" with external enforcement of cooperative behavior (e.g. through contract law).

## Key Characteristics

Several important features define cooperative games:

- In cooperative games, players share a common interest in achieving a specific goal or outcome, and the players must identify and agree on a common interest to establish the foundation and reasoning for cooperation.

- Cooperation requires communication and information exchange among the players, and players must share information about their preferences, resources, and constraints to identify opportunities for mutual gain.

- In cooperative games, agreements between players are binding and mandatory, and once the players have agreed to a particular course of action, they have an obligation to follow through, with mechanisms in place to enforce the agreements.

## Important Concepts

In cooperative game theory, the core is the set of feasible allocations or imputations where no coalition of agents can benefit by breaking away from the grand coalition, and one can think of the core corresponding to situations where it is possible to sustain cooperation among all agents.

## Evolution of Cooperation

The Evolution of Cooperation is a 1984 book written by political scientist Robert Axelrod that details a theory on the emergence of cooperation between individuals, drawing from game theory and evolutionary biology. The book explores how cooperation can emerge through strategies like "tit for tat" in repeated interactions, such as the iterated prisoner's dilemma.

Links: [{"title":"Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Collective action problem - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Collective_action_problem"},{"title":"Strong reciprocity - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Strong_reciprocity"},{"title":"CC–PP game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/CC–PP_game"},{"title":"Talk:Public goods game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Talk:Public_goods_game"},{"title":"Public good - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_good"},{"title":"Samuelson condition - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Samuelson_condition"},{"title":"Lindahl tax - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Lindahl_tax"},{"title":"Dictator game - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Dictator_game"},{"title":"Public bad - Wikipedia","url":"https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_bad"}]

## Public Goods Game - Search Results

Based on the search results, here's information about the public goods game:

### Definition and Basic Setup

The public goods game is a standard of experimental economics.(no content)In the basic game, subjects secretly choose how many of their private tokens to put into a public pot. More specifically, each participant is given some amount of money, they are then allowed to contribute any of their allocation to a common pool, and the common pool is then multiplied by some amount greater than one, then evenly redistributed to each participant, regardless of how much they contributed.

### Applications and Relevance

Public goods games are valuable in understanding the role of incentives in an individual's behaviours and arise from behavioural economics and have broad applications to societal challenges.(no content)Examples of applications include environmental policy, legal and justice issues and workplace and organisational structures.

### Experimental Findings

Interestingly, experimental results often contradict rational economic predictions. For anyone trying to maximize their payoff, the rational nash equilibrium strategy is to not contribute anything. However, the Nash equilibrium is rarely seen in experiments; people do tend to add something into the pot, with actual levels of contribution varying widely (anywhere from 0% to 100% of initial endowment).

### Effects of Transparency and Competition

If the amount contributed by each group member is not hidden, the amount contributed tends to be significantly higher. Additionally, in one-shot games, competition increases cooperation with/out incentives, while in finitely repeated games, cooperation is sustained with incentives.

## Public Goods Game - Search Results

Based on the search results, here's information about the public goods game:

### Definition and Basic Setup

The public goods game is a standard of experimental economics.(no content)In the basic game, subjects secretly choose how many of their private tokens to put into a public pot. More specifically, each participant is given some amount of money, they are then allowed to contribute any of their allocation to a common pool, and the common pool is then multiplied by some amount greater than one, then evenly redistributed to each participant, regardless of how much they contributed.

### Applications and Relevance

Public goods games are valuable in understanding the role of incentives in an individual's behaviours and arise from behavioural economics and have broad applications to societal challenges.(no content)Examples of applications include environmental policy, legal and justice issues and workplace and organisational structures.

### Experimental Findings

Interestingly, experimental results often contradict rational economic predictions. For anyone trying to maximize their payoff, the rational nash equilibrium strategy is to not contribute anything. However, the Nash equilibrium is rarely seen in experiments; people do tend to add something into the pot, with actual levels of contribution varying widely (anywhere from 0% to 100% of initial endowment).

### Effects of Transparency and Competition

If the amount contributed by each group member is not hidden, the amount contributed tends to be significantly higher. Additionally, in one-shot games, competition increases cooperation with/out incentives, while in finitely repeated games, cooperation is sustained with incentives.

## Search Results for "Evolutionary Dynamics"

Here's what I found about evolutionary dynamics:

### Definition
Evolutionary dynamics is the study of the mathematical principles according to which biological organisms as well as cultural ideas evolve and evolved, mostly achieved through the mathematical discipline of population genetics, along with evolutionary game theory.

### Key Related Concepts

**Eco-evolutionary Dynamics:** Eco-evolutionary dynamics refers to the reciprocal effects that ecology and evolution have on each other.(no content)Evolution can operate on fine time scales simultaneously with ecological processes.

**Evolutionary Game Theory:** Evolutionary game theory differs from classical game theory in focusing more on the dynamics of strategy change, which is influenced by the frequency of the competing strategies in the population.

**Adaptive Dynamics:** Evolutionary invasion analysis, also known as adaptive dynamics, is a set of mathematical modeling techniques that use differential equations to study the long-term evolution of traits in asexually and sexually reproducing populations.

### Evolutionary Arms Race
An evolutionary arms race is an ongoing struggle between competing sets of co-evolving genes, phenotypic and behavioral traits that develop escalating adaptations and counter-adaptations against each other.

These search results provide a comprehensive overview of evolutionary dynamics from multiple perspectives, including its mathematical foundations, interactions with ecology, and various applications to understand evolution in natural systems.

I found search results for "network hub" that cover several different meanings of the term. Here's what the search returned:

## Networking Hardware

An Ethernet hub (also called a network hub, repeater hub, multiport repeater) is a network hardware device for connecting multiple Ethernet devices together and making them act as a single network segment.(no content)A layer 1 network device such as a hub transfers data but does not manage any of the traffic coming through it, and any packet entering a port is repeated to the output of every other port except for the port of entry.

It's worth noting that as of 2011, connecting network segments by repeaters or hubs is deprecated by IEEE 802.3.(no content)A switch is more intelligent than an Ethernet hub, which simply retransmits packets out of every port of the hub except the port on which the packet was received.

## Network Science

In network science, a hub is a component of a network with a high-degree node that has a significantly larger number of links in comparison with other nodes in the network.

## Other Meanings

The search also returned results for physical locations and organizations called "network hubs," including coworking spaces and rail transportation networks, but the primary technical definition refers to networking hardware or network topology concepts.

todos.content: List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.
todos.activeForm: Listing all triples from title/abstract

todos.content: For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.
todos.activeForm: Searching for Wikipedia articles for each triple

todos.content: Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters
todos.activeForm: Editing triples_output.json with all triple information

todos.content: Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py
todos.activeForm: Running validation script

todos.content: If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.
todos.activeForm: Fixing validation errors

Here are the search results for "synergy":

## Definition and General Concept

Synergy is the concept that a combined effect of two or more entities is greater than the sum of their individual effects.(no content)The term synergy comes from the Attic Greek word συνεργία synergia from synergos, meaning "working together".

## Applications Across Different Fields

**Business Context:**
In a business context, synergy suggests that a team can produce a superior result compared to what its members could achieve individually. More specifically, corporate synergy occurs when corporations interact congruently with one another, creating additional value.

**Biology and Evolution:**
In the biological sciences, synergy is seen as a key driver of evolution. The Synergism Hypothesis, proposed by Peter Corning, suggests that the cooperative relationships at all levels of living systems, from genes to social groups, are favored by natural selection because they provide functional advantages for survival and reproduction.

**Medicine and Pharmacology:**
In toxicology and pharmacology, the combined effect of multiple substances, such as drugs or toxins, can be significantly greater than their individual effects, a phenomenon known as drug synergy. This can be both beneficial, as in combination drug therapies, or harmful, as in the case of combined exposure to toxic chemicals.

**Theology:**
In Christian theology, synergism is the idea that salvation involves cooperation between divine grace and human freedom.

The search results also include information about specific entities named Synergy, such as software applications, corporations, and energy providers.


REMINDER: You MUST include the sources above in your response to the user using markdown hyperlinks.

message_text:
1. [completed] Read ./triples_output.json. Classify paper as "contribution" or "survey". Edit triples_output.json to set paper_type field.

2. [completed] List ALL triples EXPLICITLY mentioned in title/abstract. For each, determine entity_type and relation.

3. [completed] For each triple: Use WebSearch tool with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] to search "[entity name]" to find the correct Wikipedia article. IMPORTANT: Always include allowed_domains parameter to restrict to English Wikipedia.

4. [completed] Edit triples_output.json to add all triples. For each triple: name: Use the Wikipedia article title (e.g., "Gradient descent" not "gradient descent algorithm"), relation: how paper relates to entity (uses or proposes), entity_type: one of task, method, data, artifact, tool, concept, other, wikipedia_url: The Wikipedia URL from search results (must start with https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/), relevance: 1 sentence explaining why it matters

5. [completed] Run validation: python validate_triple_json.py

6. [completed] If validation errors: Fix the errors (use WebSearch with allowed_domains=["en.wikipedia.org"] again if needed for incorrect URLs), edit triples_output.json, and rerun validation. MUST REPEAT until validation passes.

message_text:
Excellent! All tasks are complete. Let me provide a summary of what was accomplished:

## Analysis Complete ✅

I've successfully analyzed the paper "Evolutionary dynamics of higher-order interactions in social networks" and extracted all key entities and relationships. Here's what was completed:

### Paper Classification
- **Type**: Contribution (the paper proposes novel frameworks and methods)

### Extracted Triples (8 total)

**Uses Relations (7):**
1. **Social Network** (concept) - Foundational framework for studying cooperative dynamics
2. **Public Goods Game** (method) - Game-theoretic model for analyzing group contributions
3. **Hypergraph** (concept) - Mathematical structure for representing higher-order interactions
4. **Replicator Equation** (method) - Framework for modeling strategy evolution in populations
5. **Evolutionary Dynamics** (concept) - Theoretical foundation for understanding evolution of cooperation
6. **Hub (Network Science)** (concept) - Network nodes that influence information flow
7. **Cooperative Game Theory** (concept) - Framework for analyzing coalition formation

**Proposes Relations (1):**
1. **Synergy** (concept) - Novel method to empirically extract synergy factor dependence on group size

### Validation
✅ All validation checks passed successfully with:
- Correct paper type classification
- At least 1 "proposes" relation (required for contribution papers)
- All Wikipedia URLs verified and correct
- Entity types properly assigned

The triples_output.json file is now complete and ready for use.

Sources:
- [Social Network](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Social_network)
- [Public Goods Game](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Public_goods_game)
- [Hypergraph](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hypergraph)
- [Replicator Equation](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Replicator_equation)
- [Evolutionary Dynamics](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Evolutionary_dynamics)
- [Hub (Network Science)](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Hub_(network_science))
- [Cooperative Game Theory](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Cooperative_game_theory)
- [Synergy](https://en.wikipedia.org/wiki/Synergy)
